summary_reasoning: The report demonstrates strong analytical depth by linking segment mix and operational changes to profitability. It explains why results occur: AWS and advertising carry higher margins, creating a mix shift that expands corporate margins, and operational initiatives (multi-hub, robotics) improve efficiency. Examples include “AWS and advertising growth should continue to outpace e-commerce,” and “each of these segments drives higher margins.” Inference quality is solid: explicit, quantified forecasts for key drivers (“We model total retail-related revenue growing at an 8% CAGR,” “AWS revenue growing at a 16% CAGR”), margin expansion (“operating margin expanding from 11% (actual)”), and detailed multi-year financial projections. Data use is extensive, with DCF parameters (WACC, tax rate) and benchmarking (advertising margins compared to Facebook). There is at least one quantified sensitivity—“increase of at least 20%” from a 100-basis-point discount rate change—and short-term headwinds are causally noted (“Project Kuiper will likely pressure margins”). Uncertainty and counterpoints are treated via regulatory risks, tariffs, and capacity constraints, though broader scenario ranges are limited. Actionable implications are clear: near-term margin pressure from Kuiper and capacity adds doesn’t derail the long-term path of mix-driven margin expansion. Key excerpts: “AWS and advertising growth should continue to outpace e-commerce,” “each of these segments drives higher margins,” “We model total retail-related revenue growing at an 8% CAGR,” “AWS revenue growing at a 16% CAGR,” “operating margin expanding from 11% (actual),” “Project Kuiper will likely pressure margins,” “increase of at least 20%.”

missing_mechanisms: Specific cost levers behind margin expansion not quantified
unsupported_assumptions: Stage II EBI growth 8.8% lacks benchmarking; WACC 8.7% not peer-compared
lack_of_sensitivity: No quantified ranges for AWS/advertising CAGRs or tariff/Kuiper impacts
